intro: Ocampoa cucullata, commonly known as the hooded ocampoa, is a flowering plant native to the Andes region of South America. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant features a basal rosette of narrow, silvery-gray leaves that are covered in fine hairs. Its most distinctive feature is the striking, showy inflorescence that resembles a hood, giving it its common name. Ocampoa cucullata is often found in rocky or alpine environments, where it thrives in cool, moist conditions.
